article.title: On the smallest snarks with oddness 4 and connectivity 2

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the snark depicted in Figure 1?
choices: It is the smallest known snark with oddness 4.
It was previously unknown and contradicts a claim made in a research paper.
It has the highest cyclic connectivity among all known snarks with oddness 4.
It was used to disprove the cycle double cover conjecture.

multiple_choice_question.text: What makes the snark shown in Figure 2 noteworthy?
choices: It has the smallest number of vertices among snarks with oddness 4 and girth at least 4.
It possesses the largest automorphism group among all snarks with oddness 4 up to 34 vertices.
It represents the only known example of a snark with oddness 4 and connectivity 3.
It was discovered using a novel algorithm for generating cubic graphs.

multiple_choice_question.text: What information does Table 1 primarily convey?
choices: The distribution of snarks with girth at least 4 based on their order and connectivity.
The relationship between oddness and chromatic index for cubic graphs.
The number of snarks with oddness 4 within the set of all snarks with girth at least 4.
The computational complexity of determining the oddness of a bridgeless cubic graph.

multiple_choice_question.text: What can be inferred from Proposition 3?
choices: Snarks with oddness 6 are rarer than snarks with oddness 4.
There are no 2-connected snarks with oddness 6 and fewer than 36 vertices.
All 2-connected snarks with at least 36 vertices have oddness of at least 6.
Determining the smallest 2-connected snark with oddness 6 requires further research.
